title: plod love all this the coronavirus lockdown is a chance to push us around a bit more
story: I have spent so much time preparing for the apocalypse — and all to no avail.Do you know, I have a top-of-the-range Geiger counter. And a blast-proof cellar ready to be fitted with an air-filtration system.The bunk beds are waiting to be assembled. I can tell you all you need to know about the decay cycle of radioactive Cobalt-. I even have iodine tablets.See  I chose THE WRONG BLOODY APOCALYPSE.I thought it was going to be nuclear bombs raining down on us. And I was well ready.But when the Four Horsemen eventually turned up, it wasn’t with nukes. It was with a bit of a bad cough.What I needed wasn’t a Geiger counter, but a ventilator. And paracetamol. How was I to know Probably because I was a Cold War kid and that’s how we all expected to go back then.Anyway, I might put my Geiger counter on Ebay.I’m asking £ or six rolls of toilet paper and some tinned tomatoes. And a Twix.And so here, in week two of the Great Lockdown, I’m pretty much useless.Unless you want to know the proportions of lead and concrete needed to minimise the radioactive fallout from a ten-megaton blast.One thing is bothering me, however.And that’s the Old Bill getting a bit overzealous in pursuit of people. Ordinary people going for a walk.A friend of mine was walking her dog in a London park when two rozzers turned up on horseback.They told her not to throw a ball for the dog.Why not  Because it might have Covid- on its fur and bump into someone .Um . . . might not the police horses also have Covid- on their fur And then there’s the Derbyshire coppers sending a drone to harass some bloke out for a walk in the Peak District. Entirely alone, not a danger to anyone.The chief plod of Derbyshire has been defending his force’s actions.Meanwhile, other forces have been naming and shaming the alleged “covidiots” on social media.I don’t think the Old Bill have ever been happier. They’re loving this.I know we must not take unnecessary journeys.I know we need to employ social distancing.People holding house parties and so on is crazy.I think the vast majority of us grasp this.But this is a tricky time. The public needs to be kept onside.We need to be able to respect our police, just as we respect the Government’s advice.Overzealous behaviour by the coppers does not help.Why should a bloke not swig from a can of beer in a park How is that more dangerous than taking your dog for a walk Why is being totally alone in a wilderness area a danger to other people There needs to be some common sense employed.Meanwhile, regarding my Geiger counter, the batteries are included.And for an extra roll of bog paper I’ll throw in the full-colour chart showing the ious symptoms of radiation poisoning.To follow us on Facebook, simply Like our Coronavirus page.Get Britains best-selling newspaper delivered to your smartphone or tablet each day - find out more.THE wildle is just loving this lockdown, though.I’ve never seen so many foxes, badgers and deer out where I live.It’s because people aren’t going out.And I like the thought that the animals are always there, just waiting for us humans to come a cropper.I also enjoyed the patrol of goats which have taken over the Welsh resort of Llandudno.Watch your backs, you goats.MIDDLE CLASS: Sacking the nanny and the cleaner in case they give the virus to Cressida, two, and Wolfgang, four.Growing hydroponic vegetables in the annex, enough for half a salad by next Feb.Writing letters of complaint to the board of Waitrose about the unavailability of dried black limes and manchego.Stockpiling hummus.Cycling round the local park wearing chemical warfare gear.Trying, desperately, to sell their three-bedroom cottage in North East Italy.Washing their hands every  seconds with Duchy Original Organic Fairtrade Hand Sanitiser.Trying to fit a face mask on Corbyn, their Labrador.Removing the back seats from the Range Rover for the next click and collect.Hoping to get a nice postcard from their oldest son, Oliver, who has been on his gap year in Wuhan.WORKING CLASS: Getting p***ed watching Netflix.ONE of the surprising benefactors of this virus has been the BBC.Only a couple of months ago its very existence was in doubt.The Government was planning to decriminalise non-payment of its licence fee.People were sick to the back teeth of its patent political bias.But in general, it’s done very well during this crisis.Some of its news programmes have adapted brilliantly.Not Newsnight, obvs, which is still a jabbering gripefest.But the Radio Four PM programme has been excellent.It’s presenter, Evan Davis, has an affable calmness – and he asks the right questions.Radio Five has adapted well, too – although I’d junk ALL of the sport right now.Butonly the BBC could cover politics with the same lack of bias it is now using to cover the pandemic.I SAW that a bully Builder Who Shot His Partner, Their Two Daughters, Four and Two, Their Pet Dog and Then Himself At Their £, Sussex home was described as “a nasty Piece Of Work” by a Neighbour.Sheesh! Really  Was he  Well, blow me down.You can create your own similar story by having a neighbour state the bleedin’ obvious in any tale you fancy.“Woman, , Who Died After Eating , Cadbury Creme Eggs and  Daim Bars ‘Liked Chocolate’ Says Neighbour.”Over to you.I THINK my favourite observation online about this wretched virus was this. “January  – yeah, this is gonna be MY year!“March  – wiping my a*** with a Pot Noodle lid.”It is all a bit grim. And we’ve only been under lockdown for a week or so.But I’m slightly with Piers Morgan when he says “man up”.My dad was a working-class bloke from the North East of England.He got himself into a grammar school and had a chance to go to university. But the war stopped that.At  he was serving on a motor torpedo boat in the channel.My mum, meanwhile, was evacuated as a kid, taken away from her parents. Then her house was bombed flat.In  the Luftwaffe bombed our cities every night, death raining down.That strikes me as being real hardship.All we’ve been asked to do is sit on the sofa for a while, eating crisps.I think we can probably get through this, you know.THINGS nobody has been talking about, anywhere, since the crisis hit us.This last one is the most interesting.At times like this nobody caresyou’re black, white, brown, gay, transgender, Muslim or Jewish.Everyone grasps that we’re all in this together.If only, once this is over, we could understand that we’re STILL in all this together.And that identity politics simply causes unnecessary isions between us.ONCE this is all over the Chinese have a few questions to answer.Mainly about the degree to which their government has not been honest.Either about the start of the virus, deaths and the rate of infection right now.And what happened to the heroic Chinese doctors who tried to warn the world  At least one has disappeared.China is a devious, totalitarian and hostile country. title: alex james guide making booze home
story: I have been making my own beer ever since I moved out of my parents’ house as a teen.Back then all department stores sold beginners’ beer-making kits.And today you can get yourself up and running in no time at all thanks to the net selling all the equipment you need.With home brewing, a big part of the satisfaction is discovering not just how easy — but also how cheap booze is to make.Beer, especially, costs next to nothing, although I’d recommend starting with cider, simply because it is much easier.Here, I show you how to make both and recommend three home brewing kits. story: A GARDEN centre owner has ripped up an unfair order to stop selling garden products due to coronavirus - as nearby supermarkets sell the same products.Exeter City Council ordered Plants Galore to stop selling plants, seeds, bulbs and other garden items, in line with the Governments ban on non essential items during the COVID- outbreak.But defiant Tony Joyner, , who co-owns three stores in Exeter, Plymouth and Newton Abbott, is refusing to acknowledge the prohibition order because nearby Aldi is allowed to still sell products.In its order dated March , Exeter City Council said Plants Galore had committed an offence under the Health ProtectionRegulations  by selling flowers and seeds.The order stated the store could itself stay open, but it must only sell tools and not plants - which is the main source of income for the business.He said: We are opening our stores, we are fully open and will stay open and this is rubbish. title: coronavirus medic begs brits stay home
story: AN exhausted paramedic battling coronavirus has begged Brits stay at home so I can see my son after she was pictured with her head in her hands at the wheel of an ambulance.Hannah Cassford was snapped looking utterly worn out as she joins the NHS frontline heroes trying to beat the killer bug.The -year-old, from south east London, was caught in a brief moment of rest as she prepared to head to another emergency coronavirus incident.The image went viral on Facebook after she posted the photo with a defiant plea to the public to stay at home during the global Covid- pandemic.She has been away from her two-year-old son Ashton for two weeks due to the risk of her work. He is being looked after by her parents.Hannah wrote: ‘‘Please stay at home. A member of the public took this photo before knocking on my window to askI was okay. We are not okay!I don’t think I realised quite how exhausted I was until seeing it from a dferent side. Yet we keep going! I miss my son and family so much! We stay here for you, so please stay home for us!The frontline NHS worker revealed the photo was taken after she had been stood down from an incident involving a patient in cardiac arrest with possible Covid-.She added: The moment provided me with a few minutes to relax and get my thoughts together before being assigned another call.In my nine years working for London Ambulance Service, I have come to expect each sht to be challenging to some degree, however, with the spread of the virus, each sht has become stressful with the fear of contracting the virus.Call rates have increased dramatically and our operational working policies and procedures are having to adapt quickly.The paramedic said the person who took the moving image tapped on her window to askshe was ok.She added: I smiled and explained that it was a very busy day for us and that I was missing my son tremendously.She then showed me the photo that she had taken. When I saw the photo it made me realise just how exhausted I was. I asked her for the photo as I thought it showed just how physically and emotionally tired the NHS staff are.It comes as the UK coronavirus death toll shot up by  today to , people - including  with no underlying health conditions.Many of the thousands of NHS workers have been forced to separate from their families during this stressful time, so as not to accidentally pass anything on to them.In one case key workers from a family are living in a tent in the garden to protect a young mum with le-threatening asthma from the risk of catching coronavirus.Emma Lendons daughter Tasha, , has been classed as one of the UKs . million most vulnerable during the Covid- crisis.And a doctor at a corona­virus-hit hospital wrote a “just in case letter to her husband and sons before going in for a sht as the fear of the virus is so great.The front-line NHS worker told how she packed clothes in case she was isolated from her family — and ordered her own goggles and overalls before going to work.Paramedic Hannah, forced to move out to protect her family, said: I also had concerns regarding contracting Covid- and then potentially taking it home – to the extent that I asked my mum and dad who live on the Isle of Wightand who are currently able to work from home, to take care of my son Ashton.He is only two and a half years old and I was very worried about possibly infecting him with the virus. It makes me sad that I do not know when I will be able to see my son, cuddle him and put him to bed.All I want is for the public to understand how important it is to follow the guidelines from the authorities and that we as NHS staff are all working as hard as we can: the sooner we beat the virus, the sooner I can join my family.A week ago, the total number of positive cases for the whole of the UK was ,.The number of people testing positive for Covid- has been rising on average by around  per cent per day - suggesting we are no closer to the curve flattening.NHS England today confirmed a further  people have died - bringing the total number of hospital deaths in the country to ,.The latest victims were aged between  and  - including  with no underlying health conditions.Positive cases for the deadly disease in the UK have also risen to , - up , from yesterday.To follow us on Facebook, simply Like our Coronavirus page.Get Britains best-selling newspaper delivered to your smartphone or tablet each day - find out more.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: government looking immunity passports people
story: NewsGovernment plans immunity passports for people to escape coronavirus lockdownBut health experts have warned that it may take  days for an immunity test to work and there is still uncertainty about whether or not immunity will last.ShareCommentsByNicola BartlettPolitical Correspondent:,  APR Updated:,  APR NewsAntibody tests are still being tested to seethey work " to FREE email alerts from Mirror - The Coronavirus BriefingSubscribeWe will use your email address to send you newsletters. Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor more information on how we use your data and your data protection rights.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailThe government is looking at immunity passports for people who had the disease to be able to escape lockdown. But health experts have warned that it may take  days before an immunity test will work and that immunity may not last forever. It came as Health Secretary Matt Hancock pledged to ramp up the number of tests - to seepeople currently have the disease - to , a day by the end of April. The government has been on the backfoot over its testing commitments for several days now failing to explain why the UK lags behind its European counterparts - testing just , a day compared to , in Germany. Today Mr Hancock said that the government was looking at an immunity certicate as a way out of the lockdown imposed on the UK in the last two weeks. He told a press conference in Downing Street: How people who have had the disease have got the antibodies and therefore have the immunity can show that and so get back as much as possible to normal le. That is an important thing that we will be doing and are looking at. But the Health Secretary said it was too early in the science of the immunity that comes from having the disease to be clear about when that might come and how it would work. He added: I wish that we could but the reason that we canapost is because the science isnapost yet advanced enough. But we have a programme of work on to understand the immunity that you get out of this, which is a global piece of work. And what you then do for people who have had the disease.  Mr Hancock, who appeared in Downing Street for the first time in a week after self isolating, said: Believe you me I have a very strong, personal interest in this one now that Iaposve been through it. Public Health Englandaposs Director of Health Improvement Professor John Newton agreed that there was still a lot of work to be done to explore how immunity to coronavirus works. He said that getting antibody tests ready was less pressing than testing to seepeople currently have covid- - partly because of the time it takes for antibodies to show up.  He said: The initial priority is for the swab tests, because those are the tests that allow the NHS to manage critically ill patients to the best they possibly can and also to allow NHS staff and other key workers to come back to work when they can. The antibody tests are ideally done  days after an infection, so in fact the requirement for the antibody test isnapost really with us yet. Both types of test are important, both are urgent, but the most urgent is the swab test so we can treat patients better and get staff back to work.  He added: The test measures your immunity and the peak of your immunity is at  days. Soyou want to tell somebody that they havenapost been infected, and theyaposre not immune, you really have to do it then to be sure.  So thataposs the point about  days. Professor Newton also explained that scientists did not yet know how immunity would work. He said that what the test measures is an antibody, so there is some immunity. But the question of whether that is enough to stop you being infected at all, or getting serious disease is something that weaposre going to need to discover as time goes on. I think we have to be optimistic that it will give some immunity, but weaposre just not quite sure how much at the moment.

title: zoom whatsapp facebook live lockdown
story: AdvertorialBest ways people are using Zoom, Whatsapp and Skype video chats while on lockdownPeople are getting creative to keep in touch and charities - including these examples supported by The Health Lottery - are full of ideasShareByDave Masters:,  APR Updated:,  APR Advertorial" to FREE email alerts from Mirror - daily newsSubscribeWe will use your email address to send you newsletters. Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor more information on how we use your data and your data protection rights.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailSocial connections are more important than ever at this time and people across the world are turning to technology to help them through the current crisis. Video chats on s such as Zoom, Whatsapp, Skype and Facebook Live have never been so popular as we all look to connect while stuck indoors. Thousands of fantastic charities across Britain act as hubs for their communities throughout the year to build connections and stay in touch. So now many of them are going online to continue their vital work keeping the most vulnerable people in society connected. Funds raised through The Health Lottery have long been used to help some of those most at risk from the virus right now. Here we look at four wonderful charities who come up with fun and innovative new ideas to support people... Skype comedy classes  Headspace Bolton provides stand-up comedy training sessions led by comedy professionals for people affected by mental health issues. The project aims to use humour to reduce the stigma and discrimination towards people with mental ill-health and improve opportunities for employment in the arts sector. To get around the self-isolation rules, the group are using Skype to run online podcasting, scriptwriting and comedy writing courses for members. English lessons over Whatsapp  English for Action London is a project that provides free English lessons to adult migrants who live in in Tower Hamlets . Due to COVID-, the group are experimenting with teaching via Skype and Whatsapp and are encouraging educators to share notes and teaching guides. Project members have also started calling round the students to check in with them and dropping groceries off to people who are self-isolating. Facebook Live choir sessions - with , people watching  The Rogues Shanty Chorus, from the Voice cLoud, is a local charity which aims to encourage interest in Suffolk’s unique coastal, cultural and musical heritage by exploring folk music and its associated traditions created by fishing communities. The project holds music sessions for parents of children in their early years, extra-curricular music workshops for young people, and a choir for local people. Although unable to meet as many of their members are within the vulnerable criteria, the group were determined that those who viewed the choir as a leline, wouldn’t go without. So theyaposve been hosting singalongs over Facebook live, with over  people watching. aposShed Happensapos show for aposSheddersapos  Men and women of all ages can access the Men’s Shed and She-Shed projects which involve bringing people together for a range of activities that involve conversation, craft and mutual support as well as more unusual activities such as wood turning, use of power equipment, novel crafts and outward community engagement . Staithes Shed had to close on th March but members have been keeping in touch via live video chats and some have even made their sheds available to help the community in any safe way, including erecting a cover at a surgery to protect those collecting prescriptions through a side window. Project Co-Ordinator Graham Storer said: The essence of Sheds is not what is made or done. It is the comradeship and family feel. That must will continue mainly through our online presence and electronically. We encourage our Shedders to keep on doing what they can at homeand wave to other locked down souls across the street! Sheds are people. The UK Men’s Shed Association has also started a weekly two hour programme on Wednesdays am – noon called Shed Happens” using Frome .FM which fans can access via the internet. title: coronavirus lockdown leaves sewers blocked
story: NewsCoronavirus lockdown leaves sewers blocked with disgusting toilet-roll substitutesSevern Trent Water, Scottish Water, Northumbrian Water and Northern Ireland Water are just some of the firms struggling to deal with a deluge of wet wipes and kitchen paperShareCommentsByJosh Payne:,  APR NewsA kitchen roll blockage is removed from a Severn Trent sewer " to FREE email alerts from Mirror - The Coronavirus BriefingSubscribeWe will use your email address to send you newsletters. Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor more information on how we use your data and your data protection rights.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailGrim photos show the state of some of Britainaposs sewers since people began resorting to toilet roll substitutes.Since the early days of the coronavirus pandemic toilet has been a hot commodity.As the one-time bathroom staple has been increasingly dficult to find, people have resorted to alternative materials. Severn Trent Water said it had received , reports of sewer blockages in a fortnight - mainly due to kitchen roll. The company described its workload as much busier than usual. Scottish Water also said it had seen a high number of sewage blockages - recording , between March  and March . Garry Kirkwood, Scottish Wateraposs sewer response manager, said: This can be an extremely distressing experience for people and cause signicant damage to property. We are calling for the support of our customers to do the right thing and not contribute to avoidable sewer chokes. Welsh Water reiterated the importance of not flushing wet wipes or kitchen rollthey are affected due to the shortage of toilet paper. Steve Wilson, Welsh Wateraposs managing director of wastewater, said: While we encourage everyone to practise good hygiene to protect against coronavirus, wet wipes and kitchen roll can be hugely damaging to our sewers.  Thames Water said their engineers had removed three huge blockages from the inlet filter screens at Beddington sewage works in Croydon in just three weeks. Adrian Wallis, Beddington sewage works manager, said: Normally we only need to jet wash the inlet screens every two to three months. Last month alone we did it three times. Southern Water, Northumbrian Water and Northern Ireland Water have also recently issued pleas to residents to only flush toilet paper. Speaking of the rise in call-outs, the sewer blockages lead at Severn Trent Water, Grant Mitchell, said: We know just how worrying it is for everyone at the moment and we want to reassure our customers that weaposre working really hard to keep our essential service running.  In the last two weeks weaposve dealt with over , reports of sewer flooding or sewer blockages in our area which is much busier than normal. And weaposre seeing more and more blockages caused by kitchen roll and wipes. We know that some people are having to resort to using a whole manner of things to substitute for toilet roll at the moment, but a sewer blockage is the last thing that anyone needs right now.  So we wanted to let everyone know that kitchen roll and wipes are not designed to break down like loo roll is so please remember to bin them otherwise you could end up blocking your sewer pipes. Mr Mitchell added: On top of doing one of the most mucky jobs out there, our teams are getting asked why theyaposre out and about a lot at the moment, but we want to reassure everyone they are only doing work that is essential.

title: family shed tears life saving
story: NewsFamily shed tears for le-saving daughter crowned worlds youngest organ donorEXCLUSIVE Hope Lee, of Newmarket. Cambridgeshire, only lived for  minutes but still made a impact on the world when her kidneys and liver cells were donated to a woman in her late twentiesShareCommentsByLouie Smith:,  APR NewsHope Lee lived for just  minutes " to FREE email alerts from Mirror - daily newsSubscribeWe will use your email address to send you newsletters. Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor more information on how we use your data and your data protection rights.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailThe sister and twin brother of the world’s youngest organ donor, Hope Lee, proudly hold up a certicate honouring the tot’s gt. Madie, nine, and four-year-old Josh showed off the honour that was sent to parents Drew Lee and Emma Thomas from the Guinness World Records. Hope died in November  shortly after she was born and her kidneys and liver cells were donated. Drew, , said of the certicates the family received: “I actually burst into tears when I opened the letter. “It was quite an emotional moment, to me this has finalised something. “Even though Hope only lived for  minutes she is still making her mark on the world. She will never be forgotten. After I’m gone someone will look at these books and read her name.”  Emma, , added: “Receiving the letter was a bit of a shock and opening it brought tears to my eyes.” The certicates read: “The youngest organ donor is Hope Lee, of Newmarket, UK, who donated her kidneys and liver cells just  minutes after she was born on  November .” Drew and Emma found out in the early stages of pregnancy Hope had the brain condition anencephaly and would not survive. But they refused to abort her after being inspired by the story of another tiny donor. Teddy Houlston lived for just  minutes before he donated his organs in . Hope’s kidneys were given to a woman in her late s.  Despite being as small as hazelnuts, the organs grew rapidly and are now of an adult size. Josh is also going from strength to strength. Drew said: “He’s a lovely little boy, very caring and loving, he’s just so adorable. “He knows he had a little sister and can recognise her photo. He’s taken finding out about Hope really well.” Drew and Emma have always spoken in support of the Mirror’s successful campaign for the ­introduction of Max and Kiera’s Law. The couple understand a doctor from Addenbrooke’s Hospital, Cambridge, who was involved with their daughter, submitted her name for the record.  Drew said: “Hope is part of history now and has left her mark on the world. In many ways we are still grieving but the world record certicates are another step towards closure.” The couple have since split. Emma still lives in Newmarket and Drew at nearby Mildenhall. Max and Keira’s Law is named after a boy who received a heart ­transplant and the girl who donated it to him. Keira Ball, from Devon, was only nine when she died in a car accident. Her dad agreed for her organs to be donated and she saved four lives, including that of Max Johnson, of ­Winsford, Cheshire. The nine-year-old had been kept alive with a mechanical pump and would have died without the transplant.

Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor more information on how we use your data and your data protection rights.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailThe Governmentaposs pledge to perform , coronavirus tests a day has unravelled into a fiasco. The country is still struggling to test , people a day for Covid- nationwide, weeks after the pandemic reached British shores. Meanwhile Germany is conducting , tests a day and the country has a much lower death rate than that of the UK. The World Health Organisationhas urged countries to apostest, test, testapos to try and get on top of the outbreak. On Wednesday , tests were carried out in the UK with the capacity for ,. But numbers overall remain low and yesterday No said just , frontline NHS staff, out of , in England, have been tested since the outbreak began. As of pm on Wednesday the overall number of deaths from the virus in the UK was ,. The fact that the number is currently low and is likely to remain so for the foreseeable future can be explained by the following reasons. Communication breakdown aposreduces testing capacity by tens of thousandsapos A breakdown in communication between Public Health Englandand the governmentaposs animal health agency may have reduced the UKaposs testing capacity by tens of thousands per week, it has been claimed. Employees at Animal and Plant Health Agencyhave been in discussion with PHE for more than two months about supporting testing efforts, reports BuzzFeed News. The news website reports that they have seen evidence of PHE sending APHA, which tests diseases among animals, conflicting information about recruiting and training scientists. One APHA scientist told BuzzFeed News: “We’re not even getting a consistent message about what they want us to do,” adding that the miscommunication with PHE was “appalling”. aposHerd immunityapos strategy suggested by Government  As the coronavirus outbreak began to worsen in early March members of the Governmentaposs aposnudge unitapos appeared to favour a strategy of herd immunity. Dr David Halpern, a psychologist who heads the Behavioural Insights Team, said on BBC News: “There’s going to be a point, assuming the epidemic flows and grows, as we think it probably will do, where you’ll want to cocoon, you’ll want to protect those at-risk groups so that they basically don’t catch the disease and by the time they come out of their cocooning, herd immunity’s been achieved in the rest of the population.” To reach herd immunity, about % of the population would need to get ill and become immune, according to Sir Patrick Vallance, the government’s chief scientic adviser. Martin Hibberd, professor of emerging infectious disease at the London School of Hygiene  Tropical Medicine, said: “I do worry that making plans that assume such a large proportion of the population will become infectedmay not be the very best that we can do.” Within a week the aposherd immunityapos strategy was scrapped and replaced with apossuppressionapos with social-distancing measures quickly ramped up. Speaking to BBC Newsnight former Health Secretary Jeremy Hunt, who had earlier criticised the aposherd immunityapos strategy said: “We changed our strategy a couple of weeks ago from the herd immunity strategy to the suppression strategy.” Government pledge to perform , tests a day  On March  - roughly six weeks after the first confirmed case of Covid- in the UK - the Government pledged that , tests a day would be performed by the week after. That target was finally reached on April  when , tests were carried out. Also on March , the Government said that , tests a day would be carried out aposwithin four weeksapos. Thereaposs no indication that they will be able to reach that target but today Prof Paul Cosford of Public Health Englandsaid that testing would hit , per day imminently. Government U-turn on the importance of testing  Last week Englandaposs deputy chief medical officer Jenny Harries said: There comes a point in a pandemic whenis not an appropriate intervention and that is the point where we moved. “Although we still do some contact tracing and testing, for example in high-risk areas like prisons and care homes, that is not an appropriate mechanism as we go forward.” However in a video message on Twitter on Wednesday evening, Mr Johnson said that increased screening would be how the UK defeats the coronavirus. I want to say a special word about testing, because it is so important, and as I have said for weeks and weeks, this is the way through, he said. This is how we will unlock the coronavirus puzzle. This is how we will defeat it in the end. At roughly the same time the prime ministeraposs video was being posted on Twitter on Wednesday night, Jonathan Van Tam, also a deputy chief medical officer, told ITVaposs Robert Peston that testing was a side issue for reducing deaths. Muddled facts on NHS frontline staff testing  On Wednesday the government said , NHS staff had been tested - despite claims more than , are off sick or self-isolating. On Thursday Downing Street claried that the testing number was in fact higher than previously said. No said there were actually two strands of testing for NHS staff - drive-through tests, which have now tested , staff, plus testing within NHS labs of frontline staff. The government claimed that this second section has tested a signicant number of NHS staff, but said the numbers will only be set out in full later on Thursday. Meanwhile, a new lab in Milton Keynes has now started taking samples from NHS staff, No claimed. Downing Street said nearly  universities, companies and research institutes agreed to lend their machines for the Milton Keynes effort and not a single institution that was asked refused”. Spare capacity to be used on NHS staff  Government ministers said on Tuesday night that they would finally start using spare capacity to test NHS staff, after even the UKaposs limited testing capacity went unfilled despite enormous demand. Itaposs understood the gap between coronavirus testing capacity and actual tests was due to a % cap on staff tests, with % reserved for patients. When medics were unable to fill the % patient quota, testing capacity went unused. With testing capacity increasing, Health Secretary Matt Hancock told the NHS to remove the cap, so all spare capacity can be used for staff and families from Wednesday. aposDunkirk-like effortapos needed to increase test numbers dramatically  Sir Paul Nurse, chief executive of the Francis Crick research institute - which will soon be able to conduct  Covid- tests a day - said a Dunkirk-style effort was needed to co-ordinate smaller laboratories and increase test numbers. We are a lot of little boats and the little boats can be effective, he said, referring to the evacuation of Allied troops from the beaches of the French city during World War Two. He added: The government has put some big boats, destroyers in place. Thataposs a bit more cumbersome to get working and we wish them all the luck to do that, but we little boats can contribute as well. A lack of materials and lab space  A global shortage of key chemicals called reagents is hampering the production of tests, No claimed this week. According to the British In Vitro Diagnostic Association, companies are working to meet demand, but the chemicals needed for dferent testing machines are dferent and the production complex. While reagent supply issues were sighted by Chancellor of the Duchy of Lancaster, Michael Gove, as a reason for the slow production of tests, this claimed was thrown into doubt on Tuesday. The Chemical Industries Association, which represents the UK’s substantial chemicals industry, told ITV that there was no shortage. What is certain however, is the fact that too little lab space has been designated for scientists to look at the tests. At first, Public Health England was only using its own eight laboratories. This has been expanded to  NHS labs, meaning  labs in total are now operational. No test is better than a bad test  Professor Chris Whitty, England’s chief medical officer, has issued a note of caution about rushing out tests that are not ready. “One thing worse than no test is a bad test, arguing that an infected doctor or nurse ly given the all clear could spread the virus through a large portion of a hospital. Some scientists have argued that the Governmentaposs stringent guidelines when it comes to testing standards, as well as types of reagents and chemicals, needed to be relaxed. “It is holding things up,” Professor Nicola Stonehouse, a molecular virologist at Leeds University, told . “If we could get over this, we could get the testing centres up and running so much faster, and that’s got to be a good thing. How is the Government planning to recty this   Today Matt Hancock said that he would be pressing the accelerator on coronavirus testing before unveiling a five-point plan that he claimed would see the UK eventually reach , tests a day. Part of the plan is to harness the capabilities of the UK private sector. In a conference call with manufacturers, inventors and commercial developers last night, the Health Secretary asked them to urgently create a major UK diagnostic capability, in line with that in Germany.  When asked about the details of the plan, Prime Minister Boris Johnsonaposs spokesman said that following complaints of shortages, the NHS had developed a new specication for the swabs used to carry out the tests which had been validated and shared with potential manufacturers. We think that provides us with a way forward to complete hundreds of thousands of tests, he said.

In todays press conference, Matt Hancock tried to give clarity on the government#xs testing strategy after a slew of sometimes contradictory statements from ministers and officials. Tests are essential for fighting the virus and nursing the economy back to health after what is expected to be the worst quarter in around a century.:Still things we dont know about coronavirusNHS England medical Director Stephen Powis said there were #xCstill things that we don#xt know about#xD coronavirus which would help plot the strategy going forwards. He said it was not known how many people are asymptomatic, or how long immunity to coronavirus lasts, or what drugs work in the treatment of the disease.:Test could potentially be done at home with a finger prick and deliver results in as little as  minutes.On introducing antibody tests, Mr Hancock said: #xCBlood tests are designed to tell whether people have had the virus and are now immune. #xCThe tests are done by taking a blood sample and looking for the presence of the right Covid- antibodies. #xCThis could potentially be done at home with a finger prick and deliver results in as little as  minutes. #xCWe are currently working with nine companies who have offered these tests and evaluating their effectiveness. #xCThese antibody blood tests offer the hope that people who think they have had the disease will know they are immune and can get back to le as much as possible as normal. But they have got to work.#xD:I still think there are reasons to be hopefulAsked during the coronavirus media briefing about whether early #xCgreen shoots#xD of recovery had finished, Professor Stephen Powis, the medical director of NHS England, said: #xCNo, I still think there are reasons to be hopeful, as I said a couple of days ago.#xCOne of the very first reasons for that is because we do see, as I have shown you, that the public is complying with the measures that the Government have laid out to reduce social contact and to stop the spread of the transmission.#xCIf we didn#xt see that happening, then I think the answer would be no but we do see that happening and it#xs important we continue to see that happening.#xCSecondly, as Sir Patrick Vallancesaid earlier in the week, we do see early academic evidence that the transmission rate in the community may have fallen below one and that#xs important becauseit#xs the case that we are no longer passing the virus on to multiple people, so to less than one person for everybody that#xs infected, then that is additional evidence that infections are going to reduce.#xD:KEY EVENTMore than £ billion of historic NHS debt written off to help trusts fight outbreakMatt Hancock announced that #xA.billion of debt at NHS trusts across the country is being written off to help them deal with the coronavirus pandemic.The Health Secretary said he had made #xA million available for community pharmacies and that he wanted to make sure #xCevery part#xD of the health and care system is supported.Read our full reportMatt Hancock leading the press conference today:Video: Government vows , coronavirus tests a day by end of April:Emotive words from Matt Hancock - but NHS workers need better protectionMatt Hancock paid an emotional tribute to NHS staff who have lost their lives, and expressed his #xCdeepest condolences#xD to the friends and families of all coronavirus victims. #xCIf the past few weeks have shown us anything, it#xs that we are steadfast as a country in our resolve to defeat this invisible killer,#xD he said. #xCI am profoundly moved by the compassion and the commitment that we are seeing from people right across the country, and in the health and care system we have lost colleagues too. #xCDoctors, nurses, mental health professionals: they have paid the ultimate price for their service - working to care for others. #xCI just want to say this on behalf of all my colleagues in health and social care: I am awed by the dedication of colleagues on the frontline, every single person, who contributes to the running of this erse and caring institution that our nation holds so dear. #xCMany of those who have died who are from the NHS were people who came to this country to make a dference, and they did, and they#xve given their lives in sacrice, and we salute them.#xDDowning Street also faced anger over the availability of protective equipment for NHS staff.Earlier today the government admitted its coronavirus testing regime does not go far enough after days of anger at the slow progress on checks for Covid-.:Matt Hancock forced to defend prioritising testing of patients over NHS staffAt the ongoing press briefing, Hancock defended his decision to prioritise testing of patients over NHS staff and said he thought any health secretary would have done the same. He said: #xCI understand why NHS staff want tests, so they can get back to the front line, of course I do. #xCBut I took the decision that the first priority has to be the patients for whom the results of a test could be the dference in treatment that is the dference between le and death. #xCI believe anybody in my shoes would have taken the same decision.#xD Mr Hancock said there was a #xCchallenge#xD in ensuring the public could have #xCconfidence#xD in the tests being used on NHS staff. story: NewsMum of six-year-old twins dies of coronavirus despite no underlying conditionsCaroline Saunbys grieving sister says the death of the -year-old mum of two boys shows that coronavirus presents a deadly risk to young and healthy people tooShareCommentsByToni GuillotTalia ShadwellReporter:,  APR Updated:,  APR NewsCaroline Saunby, , was a beloved mother of two with no known underlying health conditions" to FREE email alerts from Mirror - The Coronavirus BriefingSubscribeWe will use your email address to send you newsletters. Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor more information on how we use your data and your data protection rights.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailA mum of twin boys has died in hospital just days after falling ill with contracting coronavirus symptoms  - despite having no underlying health conditions. Caroline Saunby, , from New Marske, North Yorkshire, died at James Cook University Hospital on Sunday, reports Teesside Live. Her grieving twin sister Sarah Jarvis issued a stark after the death of the mum of two six-year-old boys death, which she said had ripped their shocked family apart. Mrs Jarvis warned that the tragedy showed that the deadly illness could strike anyone, saying her sister had taken every precaution under the sun. She told The Sun : People believe that because they are young and healthy they arenapost at risk but are the reality of how coronavirus can change anyoneaposs le. Mrs Jarvis described her sister as a germaphobe who washed her hands constantly. She said: She was practising social distancing, she was washing her hands, took hers and everyoneaposs safety seriously, was healthy - yet she was taken from us in only four days. This virus does not discriminate. Teesside Live reports that the said the mum had began getting symptoms of the virus on Thursday and had originally thought her sore throat was a bout of tonsillitis. But by Sunday Mrs Saunby was experiencing breathing dficulties and she had collapsed at home. An ambulance and air ambulance were rushed to her home, where she was placed on ventilator support. She was then taken to hospital, where she later tragically died.  Mrs Saunby left behind her husband and two young boys. It is not known where she caught the illness, and the rest of both the Jarvis and Saunby families are now self-isolating. Mrs Jarvis added that it was heartbreaking that the family could not mourn together. She said: Every part of our family in lockdown and we can’t console Carolineaposs boys or our parents or each other. We can’t have a funeral to celebrate her le. This is our reality waiting to seeher husband will get ill. Please listen to this and take this as a warning to us all what is happening right now. In a  Facebook  post, Mrs Jarvis wrote: Our lives have been ripped apart forever by this horrendous virus that people still are not taking seriously enough. Caroline was , fit and healthy with no existing conditions and she was taken from us in four days. When will people start to take this as seriously as it needs to be   Sarah went on to pay tribute to her sister, saying: She was just the most kind, selfless generous loyal person you would ever meet, Sarah wrote on social media. Nothing was ever too much trouble she couldnapost help being kind to all creatures and was loved by so many. My only solace is knowing that she achieved her biggest goals in le meeting the love of her le and getting married and having her beautul boys. The tragedy came as the number of UK coronavirus of deaths soared by  in one day yesterday - to a total of , as of pm on March .

Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor more information on how we use your data and your data protection rights.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailA brave woman moans out in aposunbelievable painapos as she is tested for coronavirus as she warns people to stay indoors. The unnamed patient filmed a nurse taking the invasive nasal swab at a hospital in Florida. But she says that although the procedure felt like they rip your membrane it was nothing compared to what could happen to you.  She tweeted: The worst part is not the test guys, the worst part is dying alone. Once you are quarantined in the hospital your family can’t visit. If you go into resp failure they alert your family. The next call is to say you’ve passed. No good byes, no hugs, nothing. Plz stay home #corona People have been horried to see the deep nasal swab that it involves sharing the video thousands of times.  The caption with the video reads: In case you were wondering what the Corona Virus test [is] like. As she moans, a nurse can be heard saying in the background: I know sweetheart, I wish there was a better way we could test it. In a follow-up tweet, the woman, from Panama, Florida, said that the test had come back negative. Since sharing her video, it has been viewed more than four million times and retweeted , times by horried people. After viewing it, one person joked: I’m sorry but this looks worse than having the actual virus. Another begged: Please just take my blood. A third person added: Thanx for posting this hopefully ppl will stay they asses inside. I know I will cause mo ma’am........  And one person admitted the test would make sure they stay at home, as they tweeted: Thank you so much for sharing this, I know Iaposll be staying at home after watching this. For most respiratory viruses, the best place to sample is the back of the nose, because this is where high levels of organisms gather so it is much more reliable than oral sampling. Guidance from Public Health Englandsays samples for coronavirus testing should be taken from the upper respiratory tract.Called a nasopharyngeal swab, the test requires a medical professional to insert what looks like a long cotton bud as far as itaposll go into a persons nose. After this, the sample is taken it is sent off to a laboratory for testing.  It comes as the Government announced that Brits will soon be able to conduct coronavirus antibody tests at home. The finger-pricking test will detect whether a person has had the coronavirus test before and since recovered. The availability of these tests will mean NHS workers currently self-isolating couldto workthey test positive for the antibodies.

story: NewsCoronavirus: Devastating moment dad on his own finds out his baby has died behind glassJared and Sarah Gliem, from Pennsylvania, US, were not able to be together to mourn the loss of their daughter in hospital because of coronavirus self-isolation rulesShareCommentsByMatthew Dresch:,  APR NewsThis heartbreaking picture shows Jared Gliem mourning the loss of his daughter on his own due to coronavirus rules " to FREE email alerts from Mirror - The Coronavirus BriefingSubscribeWe will use your email address to send you newsletters. Sarah took a picture of her husband slumped up against a wall in the hospital just after he received the crushing news over speaker phone on March . The devastating moment took place after the mum, who was self-isolating at home, started bleeding and was rushed to hospital by Jared. When they arrived, she was taken to a hospital room, while staff told Jared he was allowed to follow them.   The girl was their second child to pass away, after another daughter called Chloe died.Neither death was linked to coronavirus, The Sun reports.Sarah said she took a picture of her husband grieving in the hospital to remind them that they were always there for each other.  She told The Sun: As I was checking in I was askinghe could come back with me because we thought we were having a miscarriage. When they said no I began to sob. He watched me through the glass door and was texting me. He told me I don’t have to be the superhero in every situation and that it was okay to not be strong enough for this. I snapped his picture when he wasn’t looking because... I wanted to always remember that in times of trouble that no matter what we had each other’s back evenwe weren’t together.

Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor more information on how we use your data and your data protection rights.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailA fingertip-sized patch could be a potential vaccine for coronavirus, researchers say. Scientists suggest that when tested in mice, it produced antibodies specic to Covid- in quantities thought to be sufficient for neutralising the virus. The vaccine is described in a paper published in EBioMedicine, which is published by The Lancet, and is thought to be the first to be reviewed by other scientists.Researchers at the University of Pittsburgh School of Medicine say they were able to act quickly because they had laid the groundwork during earlier coronavirus epidemics.Co-senior author Andrea Gambotto, associate professor of surgery at the university, said: We had previous experience on Sars-CoV in  and Mers-CoV in . These two viruses, which are closely related to Sars-CoV-, teach us that a particular protein, called a spike protein, is important for inducing immunity against the virus. We knew exactly where to fight this new virus. Thataposs why itaposs important to fund vaccine research. You never know where the next pandemic will come from. The researchers say their vaccine candidate follows a more established approach compared to the experimental mRNA vaccine candidate that has entered clinical trials in Seattle.  They have called their drug PittCoVacc, short for Pittsburgh Coronavirus Vaccine, and it uses lab-made pieces of viral protein to build immunity - the same way that current flu jabs work. The researchers also used a novel approach to deliver the drug, called a microneedle array, to increase potency.  This array is a fingertip-sized patch of  tiny needles that delivers the spike protein pieces into the skin, where the immune reaction is strongest. The patch is applied like a plaster and then the needles, which are made entirely of sugar and the protein pieces, simply dissolve into the skin.  Co-senior author Louis Falo, professor and chair of dermatology at the School of Medicine and University of Pittsburgh Medical Centre, said: We developed this to build on the original scratch method used to deliver the smallpox vaccine to the skin, but as a high-tech version that is more efficient and reproducible patient to patient. And itaposs actually pretty painless - it feels kind of like Velcro. Researchers say their system can be mass produced, and once manufactured, the vaccine can sit at room temperature until it is needed, eliminating the need for refrigeration during transport or storage.

title: council scraps parking fees across dundee in support of coronavirus key workers
story: Charges at every city council car park, and street bays, have been scrapped, the authority has confirmed.Fees had already been stopped at multi-storey car parks and Shore Terrace, a move announced last week, but now the council has expanded free parking across the city.John Alexander leader of the council said: “As the lockdown situation continues it is increasingly clear that the only people using our car parks and on-street parking will either be key workers, or those workers in our communities who are having to use bays or surface level spaces they wouldn’t normally be using.“Under those circumstances it seemed unfair and unwarranted to be asking people to pay parking charges, especiallyit required a special trip to ‘feed the meter’.“In addition because of the situation there has been a drastic reduction in the number of vehicles on the road and the need for the usual level of parking provision in the city has diminished in line with that.”“This suspension will last for a period of four weeks before it is reviewed in light of the situation at the time.”Council staff will continue to enforce parking restrictions to ensure that no vehicles are parked dangerously or causing an obstruction for other road users or pedestrians. They will also respond to complaints from the public about unsafe parking.

title: dundee man who completed just 90 minutes of unpaid work in five months given time to complete order
story: A man who completed just one-and-a-half hours of a  hour unpaid work order has been given a further year to finish it in full.However, -year-old Gary Benson # who it is claimed now has #focus and motivation# # has been told he may be waiting some time to get to work because of the coronavirus pandemic.Benson, previously of Dundee and now of Catherine Square in Perth, had been given an unpaid work order after admitting assaulting his ex-partner.He had seized the woman by the clothing, placed his hands on her neck and pinned her down at an address in Cleghorn Street on July , , and also stole a mobile phone.Dundee Sherf Court heard that Benson had only completed one-and-a-half hours of a required  hours by January , approximately five months after the order was first made.Solicitor David Duncan, acting on behalf of Benson#s agent John Boyle, told the court that Benson had spent some time on remand for the breach, which had given him time to think.#Time in custody has given him focus and motivation, and he is open to a further orderyour Ladyship is content to do that,# he told Sherf Lorna Drummond, presiding.Following consideration, the sherf opted to give Benson a second chance at completing the order # but warned him that he would not be given the same chance again.She told him: #You admitted breaching the community payback order, which was an order for  hours of unpaid work. You have only done an hour and a half of this since August last year.#I#m going to revoke that order and that#s going to be for the same amount of time and will give you  months to do that.#Because of the current emergency you probably won#t be able to get started on that straight away.#But you must comply with that and attend all the appointments that are given to you.#As a warning, she added: #If you don#t, you will just end up back here again and you won#t get another chance.#Benson was given  months to complete  hours of unpaid work.In addition, Sherf Drummond fixed a review of the order to monitor his progress, which will take place on June . title: george cran coronavirus scottish football dundee united dundee fc
story: The coronavirus pandemic has hit society with a hammer blow but there is a silver lining to be gleaned from any dark cloud.Le as we knew it has completely changed.My le currently revolves around sitting in my flat coming up with stories to keep football fans entertained during these miserable times, walking my dog and avoiding my we when she tries to get me to do the odd jobs I’ve been putting off for years.I’m sure people reading this will be in a similar boat – day after day, it’s tough to keep going with good cheer.What the situation has given me is a chance to look back and think about all the good times I’ve had since moving to Dundee six years ago.Don’t worry, I’ll not bore you with all the soppy personal stuff but, on the football pitch, there have been some great moments to be witness to.Scottish football is rich with crazy stories on the field – I’m thinking of Wato Kuate totally losing the rag at Tannadice and a rampaging Sofien Moussa picking up two yellow cards in  minutes after coming on as a sub.As much as they were funny looking back, there are a few big wins I covered for both city clubs that stand out to me.Dark Blues might be surprised at my choice for the best performance I’ve seen in recent years.It was February  at Motherwell.Paul Hartley’s team were struggling after losing Greg Stewart, Kane Hemmings and Gary Harkins and that’s why it stands out so much.This was a team without creativity but, a week after beating Rangers, they smashed ’Well - and I can’t remember a better attacking performance I was witness to from a Dundee side.By half-time, a Zak Jules own goal had been added to by two from Marcus Haber and singles from Craig Wighton and Mark O’Hara.Before that game, Dundee’s top scorers in the XI were Haber and Paul McGowan on four which tells you how astonishing it was to see them rip Mark McGhee’s Motherwell to shreds.They would lose the next seven matches and Hartley his job. Looking back, that only makes the win all the more remarkable.For United, it was a far grander venue and harks back to the good old daysof regularly competing for big trophies.The  League Cup semi-final win over Aberdeen was my first experience of covering a big club game at Hampden. It was a great day with a huge Tangerine following rewarded with an amazing comeback victory thanks to Callum Morris and Nadir Ctci headers.Everyone has their own favourites and this stoppage is a great time to reminisce – hopefully, we won’t have to do that for too long.Uefa are due to meet via video conference today to thrash out some sort of plan for sorting how the current season ends.I’m glad to hear that’s because it’s pretty much certain their initial hopes to get club football completed by the end of June won’t be coming to fruition.August seems to be the consensus and it sounds fair enough.What I expect to come out of this virtual get-together is some sort of rational plan to sort out player contracts and technical issues like that.That’s what Uefa is there for. What I don’t expect them to do is grant the SPFL’s wishes by making tough decisions on how to end this season.I can’t help but think Neil Doncasterand SFA chief Ian Maxwellare desperate for Uefa to make a sweeping decision so they can avoid any sort of responsibility when people moan.My gut feeling is the European chiefs will have a plan to get the campaign finished in the autumn and roll straight into the new one. I would dearly love our set-up to be restructured to bigger leagues, however.After watching the  Scottish Cup Final on Sunday it made me think ‘where have all the cup finals gone’ It’s been five long years since Dundee United were last in a major cup final and  for Dundee. The end of my first season at the Tele saw the Tangerines in the Scottish Cup Final and then the League Cup showpiece a year later.It just shows how quickly things can fall apart – thankfully, both seem to be putting the pieces back together.To keep me amused I’ve been watching the Leeds United documentary on Amazon. I love these shows but think they are missing a trick not doing Scottish football – imagine all the bonkers stories they’d get up here!LEE WILKIE: I have sympathy for Neil Doncaster and Ian Maxwell but they need to grab the bull by the horns and show leadership" src"https:www.eveningtelegraph fp lee-wilkie-neil-doncaster-ian-maxwell embed # secretBXEngLa" data-secret"BXEngLa" width"" "" frameborder"" marginwidth"" margin"" scrolling"no"

title: i cant thank you enough woman living with leukaemia praises tele for getting her meds delivered
story: A Dundee woman with leukaemia who was running out of medication during Covid- lockdown has praised the Tele for coming to her aid.June Brady, who was diagnosed with leukaemia three years ago, said she faced a #le or death situation# being stuck in her Ardler home.The government has ordered those living with serious underlying health conditions to self-isolate for a period of at least  weeks during the coronavirus epidemicThis meant the -year-old was unable to visit her local pharmacy on Macalpine Road to collect her monthly prescription which she relies on to relieve the side-effects of her cancer.June had attempted to contact the pharmacy to arrange for the prescription to be delivered.But despite phoning the store #hundreds# of times since Friday, she was unable to get through.Mum recovering from pneumonia claimed Angus Council initially refused to fix gas because they believed she had coronavirus" src"https:www.eveningtelegraph fp mum-recovering-from-pneumonia-claimed-angus-council-initially-refused-to-fix-gas-because-they-believed-she-had-coronavirus embed # secretVrLUeflQd" data-secret"VrLUeflQd" width"" "" frameborder"" marginwidth"" margin"" scrolling"no"#I can’t get out and order my prescriptions like Oramorph and MST tablets among a lot of others,# the former nurse explained.#I seriously need my prescriptions to be delivered as I can’t do without my morphine tablets.#I have been ringing the chemist since Friday and can’t get through to them. I#ve run out of my tablets for next week so really worried now.#The Adler resident has been left fearing the worst, believing she could be facing serious health repercussionsshe was unable to get a hold of medication before her supplies ran out. vw, px"  June said: #I have a lodger who lives with me but he is  years old. He also has asthma and epilepsy so he can#t get out to collect it either.#I used to get it delivered before they started charging for £ for delivery but now I just go up to the shop and collect it myself.#I truly think this is a le or death situation that I am facing right nowI don#t get them.#But when Tele stepped in to enquire why June had been unable to arrange for her prescription to be delivered to her doorstep, Boot#s head office was able to find a solution.#The pharmacy have now contacted me and told me they will deliver the prescription on Thursday,# June said.#They said they will deliver it free of charge and will continue to do so for the duration of the coronavirus outbreak. I hope that they are able to do this for other people in my situation, some of whom might be a lot older than me.#I am just so relieved that it#s sorted and I can#t thank you enough for helping me out.#A spokesman for Boots said: #I was sorry to hear that she has been unable to get through to our Dundee Macalpine Road store and we are grateful to you for bringing this to our attention.#I have managed to get through to the store and they have received a new prescription from the GP today and are contacting June to update her what is happening.#They will need to order some items in for tomorrow and should be in a position to dispense the prescription tomorrow. I hope this will help to ease June’s worries.#

title: lee wilkie neil doncaster ian maxwell
story: It’s been a long week of rumour and speculation since the last update we had from the SFA and the SPFL.What that radio silence hammers home most to me is a lack of leadership and decisiveness.Don’t get me wrong, I have sympathy for Ian Maxwell, Neil Doncaster  Co.This is a very complicated situation where you are unlikely to please everyone because so many doors could open up in dferent directions for clubs in terms of the current season and ongoing league structure.It melts your mind a bit when you start thinking about all the possibilities and how it could affect people but there needs to be a decision made soon.Uefa won’t do it for them, nor will Fa or English football, they need to grab the bull by the horns and show a bit of leadership.The resolution for all of this starts with them so it’s important they’re clear with their message.There’s no way they could possibly keep everybody happy but they must do something decisively and quite quickly to protect clubs and their incomes.I think most football people, myself included, would like to see the season played to a finish – eventhat is behind closed-doors.However, it’s beginning to look like we won’t see that happening at all given the current health guidelines from the UK and Scottish Governments pointing towards a longer lockdown being put in place across the country.August has been touted as the date for ato domestic football and, like I have said before, although it will be a long four months, it could be a good opportunity to restructure our gamedone correctly.It’s definitely an option and, depending on how it looks, I might even prefer that to closed-doors games.Reshuffling the leagues and increasing the number of teams will be refreshing and I think most fans would back that.Most of the clubs would be fairly happy, too, with no relegations across all four isions and promotion for the top two sides in the lower leagues.There may be some disputes about the tighter leagues and promotion play-offs but you’d like to think most would understand the extraordinary nature of the situation.Dundee would probably have been able to push Inverness right to the end and might feel a bit hard done by but it’s a really dficult one.I don’t envy the high heidyins but they’re paid to make these calls.The biggest thing that needs to be cleared up as soon as possible, for me, is the financial aspect of the shutdown.Clubs have been left in limbo by the powers that be for too long already.Many don’t have any income at all while there are still so many question marks about how they will access adequate monies from the SPFL and the SFA.It’s really important they decide what’s happening as soon as they can because clubs need to move on and plan for, what looks like, months ahead without any football.There’s so much work to do, it’s a bit of a head spinner.At this stage we’re not even taking into account the transfer window where, Dundee United in particular may be able to raise cash.I’m sure there will already have been plenty of enquiries about Lawrence Shankland.It’s probably a huge worry for a club like United. Of course, all clubs have dferent worries financially because they’re all in dferent situations.The least they deserve is clarity.Even in the summer it doesn’t take long for players to be itching to get back to football.The current situation with the coronavirus shutdown is a dferent kettle of fish entirely, though, and poses heightened mental health risks.For that reason, I was delighted to hear Tony Asghar say Dundee United are using a sport psychologist to help players stay positive.Clubs are far more equipped to deal with these things than when I started  years ago.My son Jack and I have been out on our bikes to try to break the boredom of lockdown this week.He’s been doing a lot of running as part of his training programme from Dundee but somehow I think I’ll stick to the pedals!

title: managing the coronavirus shut down has been my toughest test as dundee boss says james mcpake
story: The first year as a manager brings all sorts of challenges but James McPake admits dealing with the coronavirus from a football point of view takes the biscuit.The Dundee boss has had plenty to deal with during his debut campaign, including heavy derby defeats, issues with the law and a restless home support.Pressure has always been a major part of the role and it was ramped up during poor spells in the first half of the Championship campaign.McPake has always had more experienced heads to turn to for advice throughout his time in charge, whether assistant manager Jimmy Nicholl, technical director Gordon Strachan or someone outside the club.The current complete shutdown of Scottish football, however, is completely unprecedented.“This is one I can’t go to anyone for advice,” admits Dens gaffer McPake.“Nobody has faced anything like this. For loads of other stuff you can get advice, going on bad runs, good runs, heavy defeats, good times.“My first year has been a challenge. I always expected it would be a challenge but there was no way of expecting this to happen as manager of Dundee.“I’ve got kids not able to get to school like everyone up and down the country, people can’t go to work or getting laid off.“It is a challenge for me but nothing likeis going on in the rest of the world.”

title: on this day the victorian trio who became dundees first scotland stars
story: Today could have been the day where  years of hurt ended and Scotland finally secured its place at a major tournament again.Had they, as hoped, navigated a semi-final clash with Israel at Hampden last week, Scotland would have been in Norway or Serbia to play for a place in Euro .As it stands, none of that will happen tonight.Partly because it’s a hypothetical scenario but mainly because the coronavirus pandemic and shutdown of football has put paid to it.Those play-off clashes will now be played in June, at the earliest, with the finals themselves pushed back until next summer.Fortunately, today#s date also holds signicance historically for one of our city clubs.On March , , Dundee saw its first players earn Scots caps – three no less, in fact.Only an established club for less than a year, the Dark Blues had goalkeeper Francis Barrett, captain William Longair and winger Sandy Keillor all start for the national team against Ireland.Taking place at Cltonville’s Solitude ground in Belfast, nearly , spectators packed in as Scotland ran out - winners in a British International Championship match thanks to a Samuel Torrans own goal and John Taylor strike.Barret would go on to win just the one more cap for his country but wore the dark blue of Dundee with distinction  times.Born in Dundee on August ,  to Irish parents, he began his career at Dundee Harp – a club formed to try to emulate Celtic and Hibernian in providing a sporting focus for the catholic community in Scotland’s major cities.They had harboured ambitions to be the city’s top side before East End and Our Boys formed Dundee Football Club as we know it today in .In December of its first season, looking to bolster their back line, the Dee swooped for Harp keeper, Barrett.Their problems were clear for all to see as he became the fth goalkeeper the ‘Ten-bobbers’ used that season when he made his debut against Hearts on December .Barret remained at the club until the summer of  before signing for Newton Heath, now Manchester United, and went on to play against Dundee in a friendly – one of his  appearances for the Red Devils.Spells at New Brighton Tower, Manchester City and Aberdeen followed, before Barrett began to suffer from ill health, eventually passing away aged just  in .Hall of Fame inductee Longair, known as “Plum”, was a terric servant to Dundee – stretching back to the days of East End, for whom he signed in .The match against Ireland was Plum’s only cap in a career which also stopped in at Newton Heath as well as Sunderland, Burnley and Brighton United.Born in Dundee in , the centre-half would make  appearances for the Dee, scoring four goals and captaining the club in its first-ever fixture against Rangers in  – a - draw at West Craigie Park.Skippering the side is something Longair would do multiple times in his four spells until his retirement from playing in .He would go on to be the club’s trainer for their  Scottish Cup success and later become groundsman before his sad death aged just  in .It is estimated , people lined the streets for his funeral, showing the high regard in which the Dundonian public held him.Keillor was not only one of the first Dundee players to play for Scotland but also the first to score.Picking up four caps in total, the attacking talent also made  appearances for the Dark Blues, scoring  goals.Born in Dundee on October , , Keillor was brought up in Montrose and began his career with the Links Park side in .He joined the newly-formed Dundee FC in  with two Scotland caps already under his belt and, like Longair, played in the club’s first-ever match against Rangers.The outside-left was seen as a complete footballer with The Courier writing at the time that “he had a knack of rising to the big occasion”.And he did just that when Scotland hosted Wales at Dundee’s Carolina Port in , with Keillor getting his goal in a - win for the Scots.Keillor was awarded a testimonial against Celtic in , with , supporters turning up.He remained with the club until , playing at the new Dens Park alongside Longair, before ing to Montrose and hanging up his boots in . He died aged  in .

title: ross docherty is not surprised his former ayr united teammates are shining for the dundee clubs
story: Ayr United captain Ross Docherty insists he’s not been surprised by how well his former team-mates have fared at Dundee and Dundee United.Declan McDaid joined the Dark Blues from the Honest Men last summer, with Lawrence Shankland and Liam Smith swapping Somerset Park for Tannadice.Shankland has notched  goals in  games for the Terrors and Scotland, while Smith and McDaid have been standouts for their clubs.Goal machine Shankland has particularly impressed Docherty.“It’s not been a surprise to me at all how well he’s done,” the -year-old midfielder said.“I had every confidence in him going up there at the start of the season because he’d done it for Ayr.“We were a decent team last season but he’s gone to Dundee United and they’re dominating the league.“If he gets a chance, he’s going to score and he’s maybe been getting a bit more service up there.“He’d dried up before the league stopped but they’d been struggling as a team.“His form has seen him get caps and a goal for Scotland which is amazing.“He knowshe performs he’s going to get an opportunity.“There’s been a shortage of strikers, obviously, but you can’t take it away from Lawrence.“Boys can look at him and take confidence and encouragement, even though they might not get a Scotland cap playing in the Championship.“It’s unexpected and a bit out there but,you’re going to perform well over a period of time, there’s chances out there to better yourself.”And Doc puts a large portion of Shankland’s improvement down to the -year-old getting himself into shape mentally as well as physically after joining Ayr.The former Livingston and Airdrie man added: “With any striker when they’re going through a period of good form then it’s got to be about having confidence.“That comes from doing well and what started that off was when he came in at Ayr.“He was maybe a wee bit unfit having not done much over the summer before signing for us and he was unfit the season before – he’d be the first to admit that.“His head wasn’t right so it was a number of things but he come in, got as fit as he could and he’s just in a better space.“He was like a dferent guy to the one I played against before and, once you get that, the confidence and the ability he has makes him unstoppable in the league at times.“I’m fairly close to him and he’s a bubbly character but it’s a quiet confidence.“He wouldn’t be bragging to anyone about anything or in anyone’s face.“He knows he’s good enough and that’s probably what a lot of good players miss in this league.“He’s one where,he misses a chance, he knows he’s going to go and score the next one.”Although a dferent character, Docherty believes Smith is almost as important to the Tangerines as Shankland.“I’m not surprised he’s been one of United’s most consistent players because he was the same last season at Ayr.“He came in and flew under the radar but, with two or three months to go in the season, people were starting to say ‘he’s been amazing for us’.“He did it the whole season but he sometimes goes unnoticed but that’s probably because he is such a quiet boy.“He’s a steady Eddy and he and Lawrence link up well.“They did it at Ayr but when you look at us compared to what Dundee United have in terms of budget this season I’m not surprised they’ve gone and done it again.”Docherty does admit, though, that McDaid’s transformation into a left wing-back under James McPake at Dens Park was unexpected.“I’ve seen recently they’ve been playing a -- so he’s almost been playing wing-back,” he added.“I spoke to him and, obviously, as a winger you never really want to be playing there so he was kind of laughing about it!“At the end of the day, though, it shows that he has that side of his game and will benefit him in the long run.“If people maybe two years ago, and I was probably one of them, had thought that Declan McDaid would be playing wing-back they’d have laughed.“He wasn’t as good defensively but now you can see he’s really improved there.“Whenever we’ve played them or I’ve seen them on the telly he’s been one of their best players this season.“It’s brilliant for him, the same as Lawrence and Liam, that boys from Ayr can go to these other clubs and really perform.”
